snippet.title: Top 10 things to do in Rome 👫 handpicked by locals
snippet.description:
10 unique things to do in Rome, handpicked by locals. 

Find these & many more unique activities in Rome at: https://bit.ly/2sZrjPv. 

Matteo, Yanira, Gabriele and Amandio are some of the amazing locals that will show you the top things to see and do in Rome, from the best time to visit the Pantheon to the best local market for some shopping, from the most authentic gelaterias to the best spots to capture the breathtaking views of Rome!  

Withlocals reporter Martijn van der Sanden went on a trip to Rome and collected the suggestions and tips of its locals. You will find them all in this video, wrapped in a unique top 10.

What about you? What are your top things to see and do in Rome? 
Let us know & drop a comment below :)

If you liked this selection, please share it with your friends! 
And do not forget to subscribe to Withlocals channel: https://bit.ly/2Jms3cJ.  
More videos and local tips, every Tuesdays and Thursdays! 

#10 Explore Trastevere (00:19)
#9 Eat the best Italian gelato in the whole Rome (00:45)
#8 Bike along the Appia Antica (01:13)
#7 Check out Rome’s local markets: Porta Portese (01:32)
#6 Colosseum & co: how to visit Rome’s highlights the local way (02:04)
#5 Do not miss the best pizza in Rome (02:47)
#4 Ostiense street art: because Rome is not just about the main attractions (03:16)
#3 Choose the Janiculum hill for a breathtaking panorama (03:47)
#2 Eat your way through Rome’s street food (04:23)
#1 Be with the locals (05:06) 

Withlocals, the marketplace for unique travel experiences by and with locals. 

Connect with us:
Find cool local experiences: https://www.withlocals.com
Subscribe to the Withlocals Youtube channel: https://bit.ly/2Jm4oop 
Download the iOS / Android App: http://withlocals.onelink.me/mBLw
Follow us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Withlocals/ 
Follow us on IG: https://www.instagram.com/withlocals/ 
Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/Withlocals

comments.textDisplay: Borat @ 4:21 haha! Really great videos though and you're really helping me plan my Rome trip. Thanks :)
comments.textOriginal: Borat @ 4:21 haha! Really great videos though and you're really helping me plan my Rome trip. Thanks :)

replies.textDisplay:
Good to know travelers appreciate our local suggestions! Our Rome hosts especially, in this case :) Let us know if you have any further questions about the Eternal City and we will do our best to answer!
Also, before leaving have a look at our Rome page (https://bit.ly/2wQOk73) because you may find some interesting options either to kickstart your trip or to deep dive in the city - depending on what you are looking for! It is definitely at least worth it a check 😉

It's hard to say exactly which tip is the best but from watching all of your videos I get the most value from knowing when (not) to visit places and also I really appreciate that you provide the street address of places you recommend. Thanks again :)

replies.textDisplay: Hey Jan! Indeed it is :) remember: on Sunday till 2PM! Rome is fool of markets and shopping areas but there are a few that definitely need a local recommendation to be found 😉 This is a personal favourite of our Trastevere expert Gabriele (just in case, he loves accompanying travelers in the neighborhood https://bit.ly/2tcl9MK)

comments.textDisplay: This is so beautiful! I haven't seen Rome like this when i went there, now I need to go again :)))
comments.textOriginal: This is so beautiful! I haven't seen Rome like this when i went there, now I need to go again :)))

replies.textDisplay: Definitely go for it! And if you manage, try to go also beyond the city center: there is so much to discover also around the city, not just inside! For example? Gabriele - one of our locals in the video - recommends to take a look at Ostia: seaside, a large archaeological site, close to the modern town, that used to be the harbour city of ancient Rome, and a couple of interesting food places 😉
replies.textOriginal: Definitely go for it! And if you manage, try to go also beyond the city center: there is so much to discover also around the city, not just inside! For example? Gabriele - one of our locals in the video - recommends to take a look at Ostia: seaside, a large archaeological site, close to the modern town, that used to be the harbour city of ancient Rome, and a couple of interesting food places 😉

comments.textDisplay: I really want to go to Rome now!! This video is making me hungry, can't wait to try the pizza slice that the host recommended :)
comments.textOriginal: I really want to go to Rome now!! This video is making me hungry, can't wait to try the pizza slice that the host recommended :)

comments.textDisplay: Do you atleast need to learn the language?
comments.textOriginal: Do you atleast need to learn the language?

replies.textDisplay: Directly from one of our Rome locals, Gabriele: "Ciao Cocoa! Definitely learning the basics for survival (for example: "Dove è il bagno?" that is "Where is the rest room?" in English) can help. But, if I can be very honest with you, I'd say that even more important is to be ready to communicate: a perfect knowledge of the grammar does not matter at all! What counts is to be willing to understand each other & connect :) We are friendly and communicative people, always ready to walk the extra mile to understand what you are trying to say / may need! So pick a cheap vocabulary and just come visiting! You will see how much more does a smile count than a 1000 words. Ti aspetto!"
replies.textOriginal: Directly from one of our Rome locals, Gabriele: "Ciao Cocoa! Definitely learning the basics for survival (for example: "Dove è il bagno?" that is "Where is the rest room?" in English) can help. But, if I can be very honest with you, I'd say that even more important is to be ready to communicate: a perfect knowledge of the grammar does not matter at all! What counts is to be willing to understand each other & connect :) We are friendly and communicative people, always ready to walk the extra mile to understand what you are trying to say / may need! So pick a cheap vocabulary and just come visiting! You will see how much more does a smile count than a 1000 words. Ti aspetto!"

comments.textDisplay: Heard there was lots of racism towards black people there
comments.textOriginal: Heard there was lots of racism towards black people there

replies.textDisplay:
Any time Mika :) Looking forward to hearing your stories once back!
And yep, our Rome hosts are waiting for you! 🇮🇹🖐
replies.textOriginal:
Any time Mika :) Looking forward to hearing your stories once back! 
And yep, our Rome hosts are waiting for you! 🇮🇹🖐

replies.textDisplay: Withlocals thank you it helps a lot 😊 I’m still going 😊
replies.textOriginal: Withlocals thank you it helps a lot 😊 I’m still going 😊

replies.textDisplay:
Hey Mika, on behalf of the hundreds of Rome locals on our platform and on that of our whole travel community, we feel like saying it is not true. Of course forms of racism can happen everywhere and in the most unexpected moments/contexts etc. Italian people are on average very open and welcoming and racism has never been in the DNA of a people that historically emigrated abroad and was itself long discriminated. At the same time, it is also true that the current political debate over there is strongly influenced by far-right claims, which could be said of many other European cities and deserves a much more in-depth conversation in order to fully understand its origin and causes.
All of this to say that if this fear is the one that discourages you to visit that beautiful city, then you should maybe give it a second thought! Ask our locals, try to connect directly to the people that are there, and they will be the best ones to reassure you that it is totally possible to have an amazing Rome experience regardless of your descent - as it should ALWAYS be :)
Much more likely there will be other things you will suffer, as the loudness of Italians at the bar counter 😂

Hope this helps xxx
replies.textOriginal:
Hey Mika, on behalf of the hundreds of Rome locals on our platform and on that of our whole travel community, we feel like saying it is not true. Of course forms of racism can happen everywhere and in the most unexpected moments/contexts etc. Italian people are on average very open and welcoming and racism has never been in the DNA of a people that historically emigrated abroad and was itself long discriminated. At the same time, it is also true that the current political debate over there is strongly influenced by far-right claims, which could be said of many other European cities and deserves a much more in-depth conversation in order to fully understand its origin and causes. 
All of this to say that if this fear is the one that discourages you to visit that beautiful city, then you should maybe give it a second thought! Ask our locals, try to connect directly to the people that are there, and they will be the best ones to reassure you that it is totally possible to have an amazing Rome experience regardless of your descent - as it should ALWAYS be  :) 
Much more likely there will be other things you will suffer, as the loudness of Italians at the bar counter  😂

Hope this helps xxx

replies.textDisplay: +Withlocals l'idea è molto interessante! Perché non mi contattare su dina_paoloni@libero.it?! Vi aspetto!
replies.textOriginal: +Withlocals l'idea è molto interessante! Perché non mi contattare su dina_paoloni@libero.it?! Vi aspetto!

replies.textDisplay: Grazie mille Dina per aver incorporato il nostro video sul tuo sito. Ma che ne dici di consigliare pure un'esperienza Withlocals ai tuoi fortunati ospiti? 😊 Attività che possono essere modificate - dall'inizio alla fine - a seconda dei desideri e delle necessità; completamente private (tu e il Local con cui hai preso contatti) e per l'appunto 100% locali! Sfidiamo pure te, Romana come sei, a testarci! Pure a Roma se non hai tempo di andare in un'altra città  😉

comments.textDisplay:
I have been there, seen that, done that…
Romans have little cars. They drive crazy. On the roads they don't use indicator, and they park the cars like hell.
People are loud! Gelato is tasteful. Rome is the place everyone must visit once in lifetime.
comments.textOriginal:
I have been there, seen that, done that…
Romans have little cars. They drive crazy. On the roads they don't use indicator, and they park the cars like hell. 
People are loud! Gelato is tasteful. Rome is the place everyone must visit once in lifetime.

comments.textDisplay:
hi dude, its rome a safe place ?

Talking to random stranger local ? are they any scammer or some sort ?
comments.textOriginal:
hi dude, its rome a safe place ?

Talking to random stranger local ? are they any scammer or some sort ?

replies.textDisplay: Hi Andhika. Rome is a safer place than other cities both in Italy and worldwide, but it really depends on where you set your personal bar. There are also much safer places, too, as far as we could go about this topic 😂 You can talk in total tranquility with the locals, of course, but in general and regardless of the place, it would depend on how you approach people, what you ask and what you expect from them. If you want to tour around the city we would, of course, recommend connecting with our local hosts, since they are all carefully vetted, knowledgable and willing to show travelers their city. But this is only a take, the choice is all yours 😘🇮🇹
